[h1]Basic SQL Commands[/h1]

The SQL [b]SHOW [/b]statement displays information contained in the database and its tables. This helpful tool lets you keep track of your database contents and remind yourself about the structure of your tables.
For example, the [b]SHOW DATABASES[/b] command lists the databases managed by the server.[code format="sql"]SHOW DATABASES[/code]
To try out the SQL commands, install the [b]MySQL [/b]engine and the [b]PHPMyAdmin [/b]tool. Those tools are free and simple to install. 

Open [b]PHPMyAdmin[/b], and click on the [b]SQL [/b]tab to open a simple text box for entering your commands. 

Type in [b]SHOW DATABASES[/b] and click "[b]Go[/b]". The program notifies you that [i]Your SQL query has been executed successfully[/i]. All default PHPMyAdmin databases will be shown. [img id="2789" width="100%"]
[note]The easiest way to get MySQL and PHPMyAdmin is to install free tools like [b]XAMPP [/b]or [b]WAMP[/b], which include all necessary installers.[/note]

[h1]Basic SQL Commands [/h1]

The [b]SHOW TABLES[/b] command is used to display all of the tables in the currently selected MySQL database. [img id="2790" width="100%"]
[note]For our example, we have created a database, [b]my_database[/b], with a table called [b]customers[/b].[/note]

quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Basic SQL Commands[/h1]

[b]SHOW COLUMNS[/b] displays information about the columns in a given table.

The following example displays the columns in our [b]customers [/b]table:[code format="sql"][b]SHOW COLUMNS FROM[/b] customers[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2791" width="100%"]
SHOW COLUMNS displays the following values for each table column: 

[b]Field[/b]: column name
[b]Type[/b]: column data type
[b]Key[/b]: indicates whether the column is indexed
[b]Default[/b]: default value assigned to the column
[b]Extra[/b]: may contain any additional information that is available about a given column
[note]The columns for the [b]customers [/b]table have also been created using the PHPMyAdmin tool.[/note]

quizzes.textContent:
[h1]SELECT Statement[/h1]

The [b]SELECT [/b]statement is used to select data from a database.
The result is stored in a result table, which is called the [b]result-set[/b].

A [b]query [/b]may retrieve information from selected columns or from all columns in the table. 
To create a simple SELECT statement, specify the name(s) of the column(s) you need from the table.

Syntax of the SQL SELECT Statement: [code format="sql"][b]SELECT[/b] column_list
[b]FROM[/b] table_name[/code]
- [b]column_list[/b] includes one or more columns from which data is retrieved
- [b]table-name[/b] is the name of the table from which the information is retrieved

Below is the data from our [b]customers [/b]table: [img id="2792" width="100%"]
The following SQL statement selects the [b]FirstName [/b]from the [b]customers [/b]table:[code format="sql"][b]SELECT[/b] FirstName [b]FROM[/b] customers[/code]
